text: <@U1BLNM9DE|tykeal> has joined the channel
<@U0Z5FGD0V|rbuysse> has joined the channel

<@U0KM61BCP>: I'm still working on setting up dynamic slave provisioning in Jenkins. What are your requirements for the base image? Ubuntu 16.04? Or should I try to match the Travis-CI platform (Ubuntu 14.04)?

<@U0KM61BCP>: As you'd like to have things match Travis-CI, I think it would make sense to get an image setup that most closely resembles the platform and includes all the dependencies in: <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/.travis.yml>

attachments.title: hyperledger/fabric
attachments.text: fabric - Fabric is a blockchain project in Incubation proposed to the community and documented at <https://goo.gl/RYQZ5N>. Information on what Incubation entails can be found in the Hyperledger Proj...

text: <@U1BC5NF2S>: right now, x86 is based on 14.04 and z is based on 16.04
I am interested in moving to 16.04 across the board, but we need to qualify it first
I am not against trying to qualify it sooner rather than later if it is easier on your side to target 16.04
(the fact that z seems to work on 16.04 is a good sign, but still requires some testing before we can sign off on it)
I'd opt for the path of least resistance, so 14.04.
ok, as long as you don’t mind working through an eventual upgrade
targetting 14.04 puts less pressure on me for the short term, so thats a positive
Not at all.
The work I'm doing is public an available to the community, so those who have setup 16.04 on z should be able to easily contribute as well.
<@U1BC5NF2S>: cool, is the jenkins environment available somewhere I can look at?
ghaskins: <https://jenkins.hyperledger.org>
<@U0KPFAZNF>: What I'm working on will be available here: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=ci-management.git;a=summary>
<@U1BC5NF2S>: whose x86 machines is jenkins running on? LF?
<@U10Q62R8X>: Yes, LF's
would be curious to donate my rhel box for the cause.. running z that is
I am using groovy with Pipeline project to setup jenkins with slaves (x86)
<@U0UHG4VP1> mentioned yesterday that we have to use JJB.
vpaprots: what we’re building are vagrant setups to create and destroy builders on demand. how hard is it to set up (if even possible) z on an x64 intel vm?

hmm.. well.. depends how faithfully you want to emulate... I believe my rhel is a KVM instance? there are apis to create/destroy those over rest for that cloud from what I heard.. seems a bit heavy handed, but does guarantee that you start with an identical setup every time...
I was on a call with the LinuxONE admins day before yesterday.. they were asking if I would like a 'blockchain' image people can create instances out of...
we do let them live 30 minutes, I think, in case another build comes along
if I were to do it.. I would just keep the machine up, running the jenkins slave.. the trick is making sure jobs clean up after themselves (or each job starts by cleaning up if need be)
I think thats what they do to build node.js and golang.. google got three linuxone's to dispatch their ci to

I will defer to tykeal for the “why dispose every time”. I suspect it’s also to defray costs, in addition to cleaning up. We were talking about another project today with matrix builds that can spawn an amazing number of builds per update
hmm.. concurrent builds.. that would be 'interesting'
oh.. wait, I missed part of your question 'z on an x64 intel vm'
well.. if you really wanted, there is zpdt. its an emulator...
it is a completely different instruction set.. so you would be shooting yourself in the foot
we dispose of VMs after they idle for 30 minutes to defray costs
keeping a slave that isn't in use online all the time costs a lot of money
particularly since all the cloud providers bill by the hour
and yes, if the build doesn't need to be serialized (say merge jobs) then making sure the build is flagged for concurrent is something that should be done
cost of using LinuxONE is really beyond my paygrade, but we are already doing it for golang and nodejs, so there is certain precedent
hey, I'm not talking about anything z related here, just the basic x64 cloud instances ;)
:slightly_smiling_face:
heh.. I am saying chances are we will foot the bill for linuxone, just making sure if we do, that jenkins will dispatch there too

yes, I, ry and bramwelt were mentioning something about that. As I haven't worked with that infrastructure before I don't know specifically what's involved. In particular, if it's possible to spawn / drop "instances" easily with a Jenkins plugin or if it's going to have to be static slaves
all my cloud work has been in OpenStack, GCE, AWS and in my distant past VMWare
those are all pretty well known quantities to me on dynamic builders with Jenkins
its really just kvm running rhel
libvirt?
<@U11HH3P7Y> and <@U14FUGATW> already tried running jenkins slaves there
if it's libvirt based there's a slave cloud plugin that can work with those already
I believe so, but innards of kvm is done by team in germany
I've not used it so I don't know what the restrictions related to it are
I am more of a crypto assembly guy that has happened to need stable builds :slightly_smiling_face:
or compiler guy? meh
heh, well, if you can build on an x64 linux distro we can do that easily ;)
I setup my  master jenkins and salve x86 configuration and I ran go tests successfully..
I ran basic groovy script from my master jenkins which called salve and executed unit tests..
I did this setup on pipeline project.. which accepts groovy

once we actually start using the jenkins system we'll be able to easily scale out the number of systems in play at time. We've got one project currently at full capacity is utilizing ~1.25 T of RAM and between 1500 and 2000 CPU core
across a max of 250 instances
<@U1BC5NF2S>: I wonder if we can streamline the work you and <@U11HH3P7Y> are doing..

we build our instance definitions using vagrant. You can see our initial loadout here: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=ci-management.git;a=tree;f=vagrant;h=838e6879bc36f0035eea0ffc5a0c7573f04177b2;hb=HEAD>
which was just me bootstrapping a basic vagrant for ry and bramwelt to start working with ;)

<@U1BLNM9DE>: z is like arm, a different processor, with its own instructions... subtle differences sometimes really give us hard times. often somebody making x assumptions without realizing they are x specific.. but then, the higher level library you use the less you care
I'm just pointing out what we've historically done
I can try and find more about libvirt though.. not really my strength..
right.. that link is going over my head for now. I probably don't need to do this, but pass it along :slightly_smiling_face:
vpaprots: is most of your team on the east coast? I ask because tykeal bramwelt and I are west coast, and I notice you’re up pretty late :slightly_smiling_face:
yeah.. actually a good chunk of us are over in europe :slightly_smiling_face:
